To signal SSH client you are ready to listen you could close a stream (stderr for example) the test case could be listening from (using for example select).

 # Notify test case this is ready to receive
 sys.stderr.close()
 sys.stderr = sys.stdout()

 # Wait for multicast message
 message = sock.recv(1024)
 
 # Send read content and flush before exiting
 sys.stdout(message)
 sys.stdout.close()
 exit(0)

in_progress_apps is a data structure with the following format
<app_name1> : <abort_status>
<app_name2> : <abort_status>

which is used for the abort thread to "communicate" with the app processing thread that an abort request has been issued for this app. Please read the commit message regarding the implementation scope and recommend a low risk, reapply friendly alternative if you disagree with this solution. If it's just a matter of variable naming, do you have a better one in mind?
just curious, why are we setting these to "failure" when a user-requested abort isn't necessarily a failure?

As the abort does not undo everything that has been done at the time the abort took effect, the app is in partly applied/removed/updated state hence it is considered a failure with the proper progress/reason field "operation aborted by user". I think this is reasonable.

The semicolon separator will not work (without escaping) because ';' is treated as query parameter separator by most libraries (in the same was as '&'). In fact ';' is the more official separator but it never really caught on. So if you parse this query string you're not going to get what you expect:

>>> import urllib.parse as up
>>> up.parse_qs('updated_at=gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00;lt:2016-12-01T01:00:00')
{'updated_at': ['gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00']}
>>> up.parse_qs('updated_at=gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00;lt:2016-12-01T01:00:00', strict_parsing=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/parse.py", line 672, in parse_qs
    max_num_fields=max_num_fields)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/parse.py", line 725, in parse_qsl
    raise ValueError("bad query field: %r" % (name_value,))
ValueError: bad query field: 'lt:2016-12-01T01:00:00'

Since you're not really expressing a range, but rather members of a bound, ',' seems like your best bet here. '-' is already used all over the place, and ',' is common in openstack for parameters that take multiple args (e.g. in placement 'resources=VCPU:1,MEMORY_MB:1024')
Thanks, Chris, this is a really great suggestion.

specs/stein/image-encryption.rst.message:
2.2 and 2.3 are not clear to me in the context of this spec.

2.2 sounds like it isn't going to use the encryption mechanism designed here?

2.3 doesn't seem like the behavior I would expect.  If we are creating an encrypted image with the symmetric encryption described here, I would expect that encryption to be done on top of the LUKS layer used by Cinder volumes currently, not for the volume/image to be "re-encrypted".

How should these two encryption methods intersect?

Regarding 2.2: correct, we didn't want to break your current supported behavior of "inheriting" the encryption of the LUKS device. Thus, it will not use the GPG method but the LUKS method and will reflect the same behavior as before just with different metadata in the image. Would you prefer entirely removing this in favor of the proposed image encryption?

Regarding 2.3: if we were to apply the encryption on top of the LUKS layer we'd have to manage, store and transfer two keys, the key for the image encryption plus the key for the encapsulated LUKS encryption. However, we'd like to treat images and volumes as separate resources that can be transformed into one another instead.

What is the workflow?  Is this new arguments to "cinder upload-to-image"?

Can users provide a key or is the key always generated behind the scenes?

correct, the encryption should take place at the point "cinder upload-to-image". In our proposal users should provide a key-id referencing the key in the key-manger, that should be used for encryption. The key-id will then be part of the metadata of the encrypted image.

This isn't quite true if the user is using the current Cinder LUKS-encrypted volume functionality.  I'm bringing it up because in your case 2.2 below, you're proposing not to do anything at all but continue to use the current functionality.
Glance has to learn how to delete keys from Barbican when images are deleted.

I'm not sure about that.  For cases 2.1 and 2.3, iiuc, the user will supply a key_id in Barbican.  So it's possible that there will be a one-to-many relation between a key and encrypted images.  And even if you delete all the images using key K, you still might want to keep K around to use the next time you create an encrypted image.  So I think this proposal places the key management responsibility on the user (except for the LUKS case that's using the current Cinder functionality ... Glance needs to learn about that one because I believe it's a unique per-image key that's created in Barbican?).

I think it would be a good idea to make the user key management expectations explicit in the Problem Description section.

Yes, we definitely need to define this carefully...

Currently, Cinder assumes a 1:1 relationship between volumes and keys.  When uploading encrypted volumes to Glance, this assumption is kept in the same way.  (A new key is cloned just for the Glance image.)

I assume this model would extend to encrypted Glance images, but I don't know -- is there a reason to model it differently?  If so, it should be described as part of these specs...

I just want to flag this.  I'm not convinced that OpenStack SDK is the correct place for this.  There's discussion happening on this etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/library-for-image-encryption-and-decryption
We talked about this at the summit a bit -- the current plan is not to use OpenStack SDK for this.
I'm currently writing the spec for the oslo library and will update all other specs after that.

Whether the resulting volume is encrypted or not depends on the volume-type.  So it would be possible for someone to create an unencrypted volume from an encrypted image and then create an unencrypted image from the volume.  I guess that's OK?  It makes it really easy to compromise the encrypted data by mistake, though.

use case 2.3: you have a cinder-encrypted volume that you want to store in glance using the new scheme.  With the current LUKS-based encryption in Cinder, don't you need to get the volume into an unencrypted state before you can encrypt it in-flight using the new scheme?  Looking at the current code, you'd have to change the volume-type to an unencrypted type, and the only way to do that is to do a volume migration (and then only if the volume-type has an 'on-demand' migration_policy).  I guess the code could do this all behind the scenes (clone the volume, migrate the volume, convert volume to image, delete the migrated clone, probably some extra metadata management).  This seems pretty resource-intensive, though.  Is it what you have in mind, or am I completely misunderstanding how this would work?  I wonder whether we should allow only use cases 2.2 and 2.1.
encrypt/decrypt-intensive, can leverage some hardware accelerators which may already integrated in the server. So we may can allow the use case, but let user to decide whether to use the case or not.
Can we put doc about GnuPG in references part?

-1 Do users need to provide an encryption key when uploading a volume to an encrypted image? 
Is it enough to give key length and encryption format? Let Cinder create an encryption key and encrypt the image.

-1 Please also address Eric's comments in the last patch. When uploading encrypted images, Cinder creates/clones the encryption key of the image, and passes it to Glance. Glance is responsible for deletion of the encryption key.
As when deleting every encrypted volume, its encryption key is deleted. An encryption key can't be shared by more than one objects(volume or image).

specs/train/image-encryption.rst.message:
What format/metadata will be recorded?  Is it always gpg-encrypted raw, or also gpg-encrypted qcow2, etc.?

How do those appear in the Glance metadata?

You also need metadata to record that these are encrypted with gpg, so it's possible to transition to a different encryption method later if desired without causing problems.

We specify metadata properties in glance. I will add them in this description. One example is "os_decrypt_container_format" which describes the format of the payload after the decryption. Handling these formats appropriately is up to the corresponding workflows.

You can directly read from LUKS files w/ qemu-img convert -o encrypt.format=luks etc.

See
    https://review.opendev.org/#/c/597148/8/cinder/volume/drivers/remotefs.py

for an example

Thanks for the hint!
Actually we've encountered qemu-img before. However, it requires the passphrase to be supplied via a plain text file (see usage in cinder [1]). From our perspective, this is not a good start for a security related feature, so we chose not to go that route. With our proposed GPG approach, the passphrase can instead be directly passed to the library call.

The library to be introduced (in os.brick) for the encrypt/decrypt functions is supposed to define a generic architecture in a driver-like fashion that will allow other implementations besides the suggested GPG format to be added and used via the corresponding image encryption metadata. If we find a suitable solution involving qemu-img or other LUKS tools, a LUKS-based alternative could be added in the future.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/6077b3338903f6d82b43f7a2fa8de70f8fbe4ed8/cinder/image/image_utils.py#L178

How does this interact w/ image signature verification in progress here?
   https://review.opendev.org/#/c/585259/
The signature verification and the decryption of images proposed here should not interfere with each other. The signature is verified first and the decryption is happening afterwards.
Needs to be tested w/ iSCSI, RBD, and NFS, to ensure it works w/ different types of backends.
We use Ceph (RBD) as backend. Our systems are limited to this, so we would appreciate help with testing other backends.

specs/train/volume-rekey.rst.message: This isn't correct, I started w/ a driver method but it's actually done just from the create_volume flow in the manager/flow, not the driver.
I'm going to punt on RBD for Train and just cover iSCSI/FC.
Playing devil's advocate, is it possible that users would not want to rekey?  Do we need an option to not do that?

It's possible, but I'm not sure whether the perf benefit (which I assume is the only argument) of avoiding rekeying is worth the security impact.

It might be better to just tell those folks to not use encrypted volumes.

(We could add an option if we think there's a good case for it, though.)

I just learned that Barbican is implementing a spec in Train that implements a 'Consumers API' on secrets.  This basically allows you to "protect" secrets (Cinder would register as a consumer of the secrets it creates, and until it un-registers (say, when an encrypted volume is deleted), a Barbican user has to use a "force" flag to delete the secret.

The Barbican spec is https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662013/

I don't know that we can use it in Train, but it would definitely be worth a follow-up in U.

Right now, when you clone a volume, you get a new secret in Barbican in a 1-1 relation to that volume.  (It's just that the value of the secret is the same for both the original volume and the clone.)  So I imagine that most people think Cinder is already implementing the more robust security feature described in this spec.

My point is that if what Jay's devil's-advocating was something users might want, we'd already have heard about it.  So I don't think we need to add this as an option.

On the other hand ... the current implementation does allow you to recover from a mistaken deletion of Barbican secret that's associated with a non-deleted volume.  I looked at the Barbican API and it doesn't look like there's a way to set a 'protected' field on a secret (like you can on a Glance image) so that it can't be deleted until the 'protected' field is cleared.  I don't think we currently set any metadata on the secret saying that it's been created by Cinder?  That wouldn't prevent inadvertent deletion, but it might be helpful for key maintenance.

I still think that most users and operators aren't aware that recovery from a prematurely-deleted Barbican secret for a volume is currently possible.  But it is, and it feels kind of icky to take that away.  (Which I know is inconsistent with everything I've said up to this point!)  Maybe the thing to do here is what Eric mentioned above, namely, to tell people not to use encrypted volumes if they're worried about data loss.  This way, a user has a clear choice: (A) good security, but possible data loss if some bozo in your project deletes the secret out of Barbican, vs. (B) using non-encrypted images.  I don't like offering a third choice of encrypted images that can all be compromised by one leaked key.  And even with the current scheme, you could have total data loss if some joker deleted *all* the barbican secrets owned by a project.

So I'm back to fully endorsing this spec.  I'd feel better if Barbican offered 'protected' secrets, but that's a separate issue.  I think adding some kind of secret metadata ('created-by': 'cinder') would be a good improvement, though.
What I am implementing currently should work on iSCSI and FC.
Do we want to remove this since you are planning to do this after Train?

I think this may just indicate a missing feature in Cinder's current upload-to-image feature -- it doesn't seem to ever call "qemu-img convert -c" to enable compression for qcow2 image uploads.  It probably should.

Wrote a bug to track this:
    https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1824821

Thanks. I tested "qemu-img convert -c", time duration is 417 seconds. If directly use gzip, time is 303 seconds. "-c" seems really slow.

---------------------------
compress to qcow2 using -c
---------------------------
Tue Apr 16 02:26:03 PDT 2019
Tue Apr 16 02:33:00 PDT 2019
---------------------------

'gz' isn't a standard format for cloud images, is this a gzipped raw image, or a compressed qcow2 image, or what?  Please add some info on this proposed format so we can ensure this is the appropriate name for it.
It is gzipped raw image
Where will this check be added?  in volume manager?  Please add more details on what components will be modified to handle what.

This will be checked in the newly added file accelerator.py. At last this will call specific hardware's driver to check the existence.

see:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668825/1/cinder/image/accelerators/qat.py -> is_accel_exist
You are proposing to add a new 'gz' format to API, so there will be API impact that needs to be documented here.
Does this format need to be saved somewhere in db?
Just like other format did, this format would be also hardcoded in python file.
Hopefully has performance impact.
+1.  I thought the purpose of this proposal is to improve the performance of upload volume to glance as image by leveraging hardware accelerator.
Done
Deployer impact = hardware required to utilize this.
Done

See some previous work in this direction here:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/450291/

Two things:

(1) You'll need to propose a spec-lite to the glance-specs repo for this new format identifier.

(2) I think that this should be a new *container* format, not a new disk format.  The container_format tells the image consumer how the thing is packaged, and the disk_format tells the consumer what they should expect to have after the thing is unpackaged.  (I think this is similar to the OVA case--you can have an image with container_format==ova, but the disk_format can be raw or vhd or vmdk or iso depending on what's in the package.

(1)Will add glance spec-lite
(2)Thanks for your explanation. Sounds reasonable to add gz as container format. Currently the image conversion is based on disk_format. If add as a container format, that means image compression will happen after image conversion, image decompression will happen before image conversion.
I think there may also be some nova impact?
If Nova bypass cinder, then it would be impacted, because Nova need to decompress image by itself

This is going to be a problem for Horizon, because we've already returned a 202 for the upload-volume-to-image action.  Is there any way we can fail faster so that the user gets immediate feedback that a gzipped image cannot be created?

Or, do we need to allow a gzipped image to be created *even if* there is no hardware accelerator?
In the cinder weekly meeting, we agreed to switch to software solution if no hardware accelerator exist. So we always allow a gzipped image to be created.

... and I guess you fallback to software decompression?

A use case for creating an image from a volume is to move a volume from one cloud to another.  So it's possible that the source cloud has an accelerator that allows the image to be gzipped, but the target cloud does not have an accelerator available.

Or do we just say that a user should not select 'gzip' format if this is their use case?

We should fallback to software decompression if no hw accelerator exists.

gzip format is very common, and is widely supported by hw accelerators. So as long as one such accelerator exists, the work flow will go to hw.
Actually, your proposal above is a bit different.  You say that you'll fail the upload-volume-to-image action if 'gzip' is requested and a hardware accelerator is not present.
Thanks for the correction. We should switch to software in case no hw.

Related work:
    https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668943/
Thanks, will add.
wants
Done

The proposal on the Glance side is to add a container_format named 'compressed'.  I think that's what we should call it on the Cinder side as well.  We don't need to expose the algorithm to the end user (and that way we're not committed to a particular format, in case we want to change at some point).

I agree entirely.  Cinder can decide what actual compression algorithm we want to support, and we will only read/write that algorithm.  We do need to document clearly somewhere that Cinder will only support reading compressed images that have been created by Cinder.
I'm OK with this. But cinder should has a default compression type, e.g. gzip, 7z or some others. gzip is widely supported by accelerators. The default compression type can be configurable
none
Done
Shouldn't this have the same fallback when hw accelerator exists that's applied in the decompression case below?
Done, thanks
Should note here that we can just deal with the existing performance issues or that systems with improved processors could be used.  There are alternatives.

the developer who want to add support their accelerator hardware need to add the tool in volume.filters. So end user needn't to modify volume.filters
conversion

yes
Documentation will be needed.  User documentation and possibly developer documentation on how to add an additional accelerator.
make sense, thanks

Do you mean in cinder.api.schemas.volume_actions.volume_upload_image ?  Right now it accepts any string (more or less), it's not working with an enum.  Maybe we should introduce a configurable enum here so that we can control what container_format is allowed on the Cinder side (it could be a subset of what Glance allows).
correct, disk_format is controlled by enum, but container_format is not. So cinder api will not refuse the new container format even we don't add it explicitly.
this currently *is* controlled by an enum in cinder.api.schemas.volume_actions.volume_upload_image
Done

Actually, your spec has changed so that we'll be using a software solution if hardware isn't available.  So this alternative is really to use software only without introducing the complexity of using a hardware accelerator (which is a worse alternative for the reasons you say, namely, that if the hardware is available, we should use it).
revised, thanks
These are no longer necessarily true, because with the software fallback in the absence of a configured hardware accelerator, we will be consuming *more* CPU.
revised, thanks

We also have the case that if the hardware doesn't have an accelerator or if the tools aren't installed, there will be a performance impact -- unless we provide a config option to disallow the option for users to specify 'compressed' when uploading a volume to an image.  (I'm not saying that we *must* provide a config option, I'm just saying that we need to acknowledge this issue and decide what to do.)
revised, thanks

It may be worth noting here that we need to test this case in particular: when creating a volume from an image, an image with container_format == 'compressed' may contain some format other than what Cinder supports -- we need to fail gracefully.  (How you do that is an implementation detail.)

It's slightly concerning that this is only happening when the cache wasn't initialized - i.e. we will not pick up changes made in the db since the cache was populated. This requires judicious consumption of the cache: in particular, clear()ing it when we make db changes to RCs/traits. This turns out to be happening correctly in the code, but that feels kind of tightly coupled to me.

Also, we seem to be being more careful in the *_from_* methods, which check, refresh, check again.

Yeah, I thought about this a bit while doing other stuff, and I think my brain added much the same place you did:

given that the cache is now only per request, and the only way we can add or remove a trait or resource class is in the scope of a single request (in which no other action happens), it might be better to not do any clear() at all

Since this cache's purpose is "get me the state of X at the start of request and then use that state" and that state is tied to a single transactional context, keeping it as unencumbered as possible is probably the best thing.

But we'll want to document that well I suppose.

If we choose that path then there are probably some additional simplifications we can make, which continues to be good.
Yes, I'm on board with eliminating clear() altogether, but I will feel a lot more comfortable about it if we can future-proof it somehow (against "incidentally" as noted above).

I'm struggling to come up with a way to remove clear and future proof things that doesn't involve changing a lot of in the db tests and the way the gabbi fixtures operate. In the next patch I provide a bit more documentation on when/where using the cache is appropriate and put clear in any change operation.

We could remove clear entirely but that seems to introduce more risk than you're wanting to contemplate.

Future reviewers will to be clear about where clear needs to happen if the cache is used for other things.

However, I think for the most part we shouldn't use the cache for other things and we can make that relatively easy by not adding more things.

The care in the *from* needs to be different because we are concerned with individual entries, whereas here we want everything that is in the cache right now. If there is nothing in it we want to get fill it and return it. If it is still nothing, that's okay.

Or perhaps you are saying something more than it initially appears?

it is crucial that clear() happens in the places that it does. That's unfortunate but is necessary if we want to minimize db reads.

Yeah, I'm saying if we

 0: warm the cache
 1: add or remove an entry in the db
 2: get_all()

2 will get the contents of the cache as they existed at 0 -- unless 1 is always careful about clearing the cache. Now...

- We're clearing the cache in some places, but not in others, as noted in other comments. But I'm not sure if clearing the cache is necessary in any/all of those places because
- I don't think there's currently any single-context operation where we could possibly do 0,1,2. Because the only way to create or delete a trait or RC is via the explicit single-value PUT/DELETE operations on those entities (i.e. it doesn't happen incidentally as part of any other operation). And even PUT /resource_classes/$name at microversion 1.2-1.6, which is the only one of those that returns the new entity in the response, uses the local value rather than re-pulling it from the db (cache). But
- That doesn't mean we shouldn't be rigorous and future-proof against such pratfalls.

But if we're going to do that, we should do it all the way, whereas right now there seem to be some places where we update the db but don't clear the cache.

Note: this returns a generator in py3. This happens to work because all callers are iterating over the result (some multiple times, which I only recently found out actually works). And it's more efficient than converting to an extra list or set here. But it's worth being clear about in the docstring.

specs/train/approved/physical-tpm-passth.message: This is a pretty big red flag to me of adding an incomplete feature to nova from the start which will just be technical debt later. Someone will be using PTPM flavors with their pet and really need it to be migrated.
They tell me it's because the device contains data (secrets) that can't be brought along.
OK, so more like a baremetal scenario (somewhere in between). Firmware!
This goes with Dan's point below.

Yeah I read this as "when trying to assign one", but my point was more specifically about the coming-back-from-reboot case where we're like "so, um, which TPM went with which guest?". If they have a uuid or serial number then that's cool, but my point about persistence of that mapping is important. If they're always discoverable in the same order, we need to (a) make sure that damn well holds for every possible system and hardware arrangement and (b) that we handle the case where I add in a card of TPMs (if that's a thing) or transplant disks into a new system with more TPMS (or in a different topology).

This kind of thing, especially when related to the extreme security aspect, makes this very much less trivial than just making sure we get the right nic attached to a guest. I would say that giving the wrong nic to a guest is massively less concerning (even with the Coke network access it might grant to Pepsi) than giving a VM someone else's populated TPM.

And we have to make sure that we hard-pin a given TPM to a guest and NEVER hand it to another one in between reboots. This isn't like a GPU where after reboot, we can hand them to guests in whatever order as long as the type is the same. I would think we'd need some hard persistence to be absolutely sure we don't eff that up, right?

Also, how many systems actually have more than one TPM? I thought it was kinda supposed to be one per system in the early days. I know they can be partitioned to some degree now, but, can we get a read from people that know current hardware on this?

You said above that migration won't be supported. Remember that resize == cold migrate with a new flavor (though resize may potentially not move the server to another host depending on configuration and capacity).
Yeah, I knew I would be using the terminology wrong. I meant "same host resize". How do we spell that?

Are you saying we'll need special handling in the scheduler to constrain what would otherwise be a normal schedule to the same host if a TPM is passed through? Because if so, holy crap tight coupling batman. If not, I think it's better to just say "no migration of any kind" otherwise it's hard to make sure that a system is configured to allow this properly.

Also, I'm not sure about this, but I think that even the same-host resize might be a little tricky. We need to redefine the domain in libvirt with new characteristics, but the same TPM device. I always have to re-learn this, but I'm not sure how special-cased-for-same-host the libvirt resize code is.

There is an issue with how wait_for_status works. wait_for_status method has a loop that calls the function from update_resource argument. At first iteration, it calls it with  what is transmitted as the first argument to wait_for_status (lb["loadbalancer"]["id"] in our case), for the second and all other iterations update_resource function is called with the result of previous execution of it[*].
This means that for the second and all other iterations self.load_balancer_show method is executed with a dict of load_balancer, not a string with id.

it can be fixed like with adding lambda function like:

    # hope that we can make self.load_balancer_show 
    # and all other methods to return actual objs instead of {"loadbalancer": {actual obj}}
    update_resource=lambda lb: self.load_balancer_show(lb["loadbalancer"]["id"])


[*] - https://github.com/openstack/rally/blob/1.6.0/rally/task/utils.py#L214
it looks like it is not needed

specs/stein/approved/cyborg-nova-placeme.message: Can the glance image be seen by all tenants? For AFaaS, the bitstreams are provided by the cloud vendor, so it makes sense to save the bitstream in glance. But for DaaS, the bitstreams are owned by tenants, so a tenant doesn't want to others see there bitstreams. Imagine a case in DaaS, after the user developed a bitstream and saved it to the private object store, and then he/she wants to launch an instance with request-time programming, how this can be done?

Access to Glance images can be limited, and have 4 levels:
$ openstack image create ... [--public | --private | --community | --shared] ...
Private is default. Specific tenants can be given access via:
$ openstack image add project <image> <project>

Cyborg should retrieve bitstream images with the user's token. If the image was uploaded by the same tenant, that should serve to isolate access.

The glance images have 4 levels of visibility:
# openstack image create ... 
[--public | --private | --community | --shared]
ok, that is good.

I can't imagine what the use case for this example is for FPGA. For those can be re-programmed, like, bitstream for a function, pre-program is not a good idea. My understanding here is, the fpga driver needs to report what has been pro-programmed, but the driver doesn't know (actually nobody knows) whether the bitstream is a desired one. AFaaS Orchestration-Programmed is preferred since in this case, cyborg knows what is exactly on the FPGA.
pre-program is good for ASICs

The operator may want to provide a pre-programmed model for many reasons, as stated in Lines 94-102. If the device is an FPGA, this assumes that the specific function in the FPGA can be discovered by the Cyborg driver through some means. 

More broadly, Cyborg provides the same mechanisms to every device type, whether an FPGA or not.

If the Cyborg driver reports a function-id, Cyborg creates a function trait and publishes it. Say there are 2 cards, one with hello-world function H and other with a pre-programmed gzip function G. Cyborg will publish both. However, the operator would have installed device profiles only for the useful functions like G. That device profile will look like this:

{ resources:CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR_FPGA=1
  trait:CUSTOM_FPGA_FUNCTION_G=required
}

There would be none for H since the operator is not interested in it. But, if he got interested in it for whatever reason, he could create a device profile that references it. Basically, Cyborg gives all the information he needs and he can use it however he wants.

The aim is to enable devices with minimum configuration; most things are auto-discovered. As you may know, FPGAs are known to be complex to use, and we have a chance to make them operator-friendly. If the operator has to create explicit files listing what functions are allowed, it would be a pain as bitstreams and functions proliferate.

We may consider a mechanism by which the operator can assign a name to specific function IDs, and that name is used in traits instead of IDs. That can also help address this, since the operator would give a name to G but not to H.

Good comments. First, in regular operation, a compute node or an FPGA should not be power-cycled. Only some maintenance operation like FPGA updates should need that.

Secondly, when an FPGA power-cycles, the bitstream is indeed lost but some devices will auto-reload it from flash. If there is a shell logic + user logic, presumably only the shell will be reloaded.Then it is up to the operator to restore the user logic within the maintenance window.

In some cases, the entire image may be loaded as a unit (there is no shell), so reload from flash is enough. (Just considering all possibilities here.)  

Also, preprogrammed is a natural milestone of Cyborg development, right? Because the first thing we would do is discover existing functions and use them to launch VMs. Programming with DaaS or AFaaS will be the next step.

Re. #2 in your list, there seems to be a disconnect. Even if a function exists on the card, the device profile may ask for DaaS or AfaaS. Cyborg will support both for any FPGA, and it is up to the operator to define device profiles for specific use cases (DaaS or AFaaS).

For non-fpga, say an asic, the pre-programmed model makes sense. While for fpga, since the bitstream is volatile, which means when there is a power cycle, the bitstream would be lost and have to be reloaded, so maintaining a pre-programmed model is very hard to handle. Imagine some scenarios,
1. a machine learning bitsteam is pre-programmed, and the driver reports it to cyborg, then the host experiences a power  outage and recovers later, then who will reload the bitstream?
2. before a host with fpga is online to cyborg, the admin runs a helloworld to verify the fpga is working, then the helloworld bitstream is there and the driver will report there is a 'pre-programmed' bitstream, then this fpga will not be used as DaaS and will be potentially only be used for a helloworld AFaaS. That is, the driver itself has no way knowing whether the exsiting bitstream is a desired one.

So for fpga, cyborg is the only entrance to load bitstream, and the bitstream loaded by any other means are not accepted and will be ignored by cyborg. The bitstream on fpga and in cyborg db should be consistent. Whenever there is conflict, cyborg db dominates, and the fpga will be reloaded.

data center disaster (power outage), though rarely, may still happen. "operator to restore the user logic within the maintenance window" in this case, How does an operator easily know what user logic is on the fpga? He needs to query the db, right? This should have been done automatically in my imagination -- when the cyborg driver reports a null bitstream, cyborg will reload with what has been saved in the DB.

Regarding your comments to my #2, I don't get it. My meaning was, for xilinx fpga, when the fpga device driver and config tool are installed, there are always some built-in test running to verify the fpga is working, such as, a hello-world test, a dma bandwidth test, etc, so besides the shell, there is always a bitstream there already, which does have an id, if a function bitstream is preprogrammed, which has an id also, so when the cyborg drive reports the id, how to know which one is an intentionally preprogrammed?

I didn't/don't object to preprogram mode in the spec. My point is, for fpga, it seems not useful. From what I can imagine, in the AFaaS fgpa case, the functions provided are not determined by the discovery, instead, a config file should be provided depending on what kinds of function bitstreams are available in glance, then the bitstream is loaded by cyborg when the vm is launched.

when is the device profile installed by the operator?
It is highly likely we will be in this situation: 
 all fpgas have a function id, some are useful, some are not
 user wants to have a DaaS, I guest cyborg has to get one from those who don't have useful function id. 'useful' or not is determined by whether a device profile is installed, so depends on when the device profile is installed, the 'preprogrammed' bitstream would be discard for DaaS purpose.

Another issue is, the reported id is vendor specific, for xilinx, the id has no meaning, so a mapping of the id and the human readable function name must be maintained somewhere. If the driver reports the id first, how does cyborg knows what function it is? If the bitstream is not preprogrammed, cyborg knows the function first, then after driver loads the bitstream, the returned id maps to the function, then cyborg knows the mapping.

For FPGA runtime programming, after the FPGA function is assigned to vm with pci pass-through, where the mapping of pci address in vm and that in host is saved? I think Nove knows that, does cyborg save that info in its own db?
I don't have any objection. But we should first define the basics of how run-time programming will work. :)
yes, 'virsh dump' equivalent can get that info, then why the info not saved in the cyborg db? otherwise, each bitstream program needs to do the same thing to get the host pci address

The exact mechanism for run-time programming is not fully agreed upon yet (though I have a proposal). As things stand, Cyborg does not store that mapping, or even discover that for each VM. I don't know if Nova knows that either -- only the hypervisor like libvirt would know for sure.

Cyborg can use 'virsh dump xml' equivalent to find the mapping between VM PCI addresses and host PCI addresses. I don't know if that works for hypervisors other than libvirt-based ones (KVM, Xen).
+1 for the naming :)
thanks for the this description is really helps understanding what you are aiming for.
we are pretty close to finish that up so this dependency won't block you
Great!
I guess that can be done by using the same numbered request group for both devices in the allocation_candidate call.

Interesting. Say there is a device (represented as an RP in Placement), and it has two nested children RPs, with traits X and Y resp. Say I want accelerator A with trait X and accelerator B with trait Y, and  want them to be in the same device. If I say this:
    resources2:accelerator_A=1
    resources2:accelerator_B=1

    trait2:Y=required
would that work?

Unfortunately, if the user asks for 2 or more accelerators, using multiple request groups in the device profile, we wouldn't know which image trait should go with which request group.
You lost me here. How can a device profile support CUSTOM_GPU_AMD and CUTOM_FPGA_XILINX at the same time? I think an example device profile would help me understand this.
Does it mean that the trait will be on the leaf of the FPGA RP tree or that it will be on the FPGA RP and under that there will be region RPs without the trait?

Sure. I may have to revise this proposal based on your feedback. I will draw up a diagram after that revision.
with each device RP?

Does it true that the end user does not need know the <gzip-id> to get such a function i her server, instead she has to select a device profile from Cyborg API with an understandable name?
Yes. Only the operator needs to know the gzip-id. We will hopefully define a way to provide names to operators as well.

I guess nova only sees a device_profile_uuid in the server create request and then nova reads the device_profile entity from the Cyborg API and that entity might contain more fields than nova needs but nova will only use the ones needed to generate a proper placement allocation_candidate query.

1. There is a device profile name in the server create request (as part of the flavor in Phase 1, as stated in Nova spec).
2. It was originally proposed that Cyborg properties will be returned to Nova as part of the device profile, to be stored with the request groups. However, the review of the Nova spec(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603955/), that was rejected. So, the revised proposal is to not send Cyborg properties with the device profile to Nova.

Why do we need to translate the resource request from a device profiles into the Nova flavor? In the bandwidth case nova reads the resource request from the neutron port and puts that into the RequestSpec object internally.
My bad. Will rewrite.

I think as neither nova nor placement uses them it doesn't need to be listed in this spec.

ohh so I guess it is here to allow for a meaningful usage example below. Then I'm OK with it.

This is a Cyborg spec, not a Nova spec. :) The Nova spec https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603955/ is the over-arching spec, that refers to Cyborg specs, such as this one, for the details. Please review that too.

Specifically, this spec addresses only the representation in Placement: the modeling of RPs, traits, etc., and how they can be related to the use cases of interest.

specs/train/approved/cyborg-nova-placeme.message: I mean an algorithm to be offloaded, such as an AFU_ID for Intel. Not a PCI function.
The attribute you mentioned here is not the attribute associated with deployable, is it?  How Cyborg handle thest components.
Thanks for your explanation, as my understanding, there is no requirement about report these kinds of resources to placement, right?

Yes, these are device attributes, not deployable attributes. We have the *_board_info fields in the device object for this. [1]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cyborg/src/branch/master/cyborg/objects/driver_objects/driver_device.py#L38
s/device/deployable, the attribute_list is a field of deployable, the trait is associated with RP(deployable).

If there is no partial reconfiguration support, I think we can just ignore the region trait. This trait will be useless.  This can be done in driver layer, driver will check if the FPGA card support partial reconfiguration or not. If it's supported, driver will fill attribute list with CUSTOM_FPGA_REGION_xxx, otherwise it will not fill region related trait.

I agree the term 'region type' can be confusing but, when there is no PR, we treat the whole FPGA as a single region.

This trait will always be needed, even for FPGAs without PR, because there needs to be a way to express bitstream compatibility for that FPGA. That is, bitstreams for that FPGA will have metadata saying that they are synthesized for the 'region type' of that whole FPGA.

Yes, it looks like CUSTOM_FPGA_REGION_INTEL_9926AB6D6C925A68AABCA7D84C545738. (The setup scripts in the pilot code do this, but they don't include INTEL - that needs change.)

I would like more explanation in this commit message about the problem since you really have to understand the connection between the flow and the RT code to follow this (like I did below). I think the scenario is something like this:

t0: resize the instance from node1 to node2, node2 will be reporting new_flavor usage and the instance uuid is in node2 tracked_migrations

t1: resize finishes and the instance.host points at node2

t2: the update_available_resource periodic task runs on node2 which adds the instance to tracked_instances and clears it from tracked_migrations

t3: the user reverts the resize; the dest host drops the resource claim with the new_flavor but because the instance isn't in tracked_migrations and the instance_type isn't passed to drop_move_claim, the new_flavor usage isn't removed from node2 until the update_available_resource task runs on node2

If ^ is correct, that could also be the basis of a functional test to recreate the issue and confirm it is fixed with this patch.

So I guess you're familiar with Ia6d8a7909081b0b856bd7e290e234af7e42a2b38 and the functional test I wrote for that scenario? It would be nice if we had a functional test like that for this case as well since this is a lot of tightly coupled code and it can be hard to trace through, especially since it can race with whenever the update_available_resource periodic task runs (as noted in the code links below). Though I know writing a functional test to recreate this might not be very easy.

OK you're asserting that the instance uuid is not in tracked_migrations in the dest host resource tracker here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L463

so we don't automatically pull the new_flavor off the instance in that code if instance_type isn't provided, so we get here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L475

And don't update resource usage.

So why wouldn't the instance.uuid be in tracked_migrations on the dest host when reverting the resize?

When updating available resources in the RT, we get all instances on the host (the dest host in this case):

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L768

and we should be tracking it here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1272

now while the migration status is 'finished' it should still be returned here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L779

and I don't think we'd get here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1196

because this should be false (it's an incoming migration to the dest host but the instance is already tracked):

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1164

Is that your understanding of the issue as well?
